ALLEGATION: It is alleged that a foster family was not provided with
travel and clothing reimbursement.
INVESTIGATION:
I reviewed the following documents throughout the course of the investigation:
 Case Service Plan dated 11/17/20-2/13/21
 Social Work Contacts
 Emails from Foster family to agency
 DHHS policy FOM 903-9
 DHHS policy FOM 723
On 4/23/21, I spoke to Administrator 1. Administrator 1 reported she did not have all the
details but did provide the names of who to contact. Administrator 1 did report FC
Worker 1 may not have known all of the policies pertaining to reimbursement.
Details:
Foster Child 1 DOB: 5/7/14
Placement Date: 1/22/21
Removal Date: 3/4/21
On 4/23/21, I left a voicemail for Complainant 1.
On 4/27/21, I interviewed Complainant 1 via telephone. Complainant 1 reported they
had placement of Foster Child A on 1/22/21. Complainant 1 reported they live in
Caseville school districts. Foster Child A was to attend school outside of their district in
Bad Axe school district. Complainant 1 reported they called “TAT” Thumb Area Transit
for transportation for Foster Child A to get to and from school. TAT did not have a pick
up at their home, but would pick up Foster Child A at 6:00am at a pick up point in
Pigeon, Michigan. Complainant 1 reported school doesn’t start until 8am. Complainant
A reported this was not realistic plan to wake up Foster Child A at 5:00am to drop him
off at 6:00am to be placed on a bus for two hours. Due to this only option in
transportation, Complainant 1 reported to Foster Care Worker 1 that they would
transport. Complainant 1 reported Foster Care Worker 1 told them they would be
reimbursed. Foster Care Worker 1 showed them how to do the expense sheet and
stated she would get the google maps to help. Complainant 1 reported it was never an
option to take Foster Child A to a school in their district. Complainant 1 reported they
4

asked this and was told by Foster Care Worker 1 that a court order would need to be
completed to allow a school change. Complainant 1 reported they did not receive
reimbursement for clothing as well. Complainant 1 reported Foster Child A did not come
with much clothes. They then bought items and turned in the receipts. Complainant 1
reported they turned in an expense report on 2/25/21 for $1018 and on 3/3/21 for $200.
On 3/9/21, Complainant 1 reported he called Foster Care Worker 1 on 3/9/21 and
Foster Care Worker 1 reported she had not yet submitted the expense request due to
being busy with other items. Complainant 1 reported he attempted phone calls to Foster
Care Worker 1 after this phone call, but no one returned his phone calls. Complainant 1
reported after he filed a complainant the agency told him that he would be reimbursed
for half of the costs, but not the clothing or transportation to the school. Complainant 1
reported he was told he would not receiving clothing reimbursement because they had
gone to a thrift store and had a receipt that was not itemized. Complainant 1 reported he
was told he would not get transportation to school reimbursement because the court
needed to order that.
Email from Complainant 1 to FCW 1 dated 3/9/21:
Hi [FCW 1] this is [Complainant 1] do you know how long to get expense check I
spent a lot on gas and for the bills today. I see the monthly check in system.
Thank you.
Response from FCW1 to Complainant 1 dated 3/9/21:
It will likely take a couple weeks to be processed.
Email from Complainant 1 to Foster Care Worker 1 dated 4/16/21:
[FCW1] this is [Complainant 1] you replied to this on 3/9 telling me two weeks to
get my money it is now 4/16 and I see nothing done yet. I have been more than
patient but I need my money. This does not come out of your pocket and was
told me if I transported Foster Child A I would be paid…If this is not handles
ASAP I would like to know the chain of command so I can talk to them. Sorry to
be this way but foster parents should be treated better.
There was no response email to the above email.
Ono 4/19/21, Complainant 1 emailed Administrator 2 requesting the same
reimbursement money from above. Administrator 2 emailed back on 4/20/21 and
reported the payments have been put into the system. Later on 4/20/21, Administrator 2
reported that $609.09 would be reimbursed but the school travel reimbursement will not.
Administrator 2 reported “However the only way for school transportation to be paid is
for the court to order that-the foster parent transport the child and be reimbursed which
did not occur in this case.”
5

I interviewed Foster Care Worker 1 on 5/4/21. Foster Care Worker 1 reported Foster
Child A was to attend a school outside of the foster parent’s school district. Foster
Worker 1 reported she told the foster parents they could switch schools for Foster Child
A if they would like and they refused doing that. Foster Worker 1 did report she tried to
file a Determination of Care within the first 30 days of placement. Foster Care Worker 1
reported she was attempting to obtain school transportation costs for the family. Foster
Care Worker 1 reported Complainant 1 was aware she was trying to obtain travel
reimbursement for school transportation. Foster Care Worker 1 reported her supervisor
told her to remove that request and reach out to the school for transportation. Foster
Care Worker 1 reported this was when she called the school and they referred TAT.
Foster Care Worker 1 reported she was not sure on all the processes and policies for
transportation and clothing.
Foster Care Worker 1 reported she called the school and the school provided
Complainant 1 with “TAT”. Foster Care Worker 1 reported she was told by Complainant
1 that Foster Child A would have to get up early and be at the bus stop at 6:00am to be
at school at 8:00am. Foster Worker 1 reported Foster Child A would have to wait a half
hour after school as well. Foster Care Worker 1 reported she did try to help
Complainant 1 with the mileage reimbursement expense sheet. Foster Care Worker 1
reported she did print off google maps from the house to the school and then school to
DHHS building, but only for parenting visits when Complainant 1 had to pick up Foster
Child A to go to parenting time. Foster Care Worker reported there are no case notes
documenting approval for Complainant 1 to change schools for Foster A. Foster Care
Worker 1 reported she did not document this in the initial Family team Meeting (FTM).
Foster Care Worker 1 reported there was a total of $19.10 in clothing reimbursement
that was provided to Complainant 1. Foster Care Woker 1 reported $29.15 was not
reimbursed due to them not having an itemized receipt. Foster Care Woker 1 reported
she did tell Complainant 1 to buy clothing for Foster Child A. Foster Care Worker 1
reported she does not have a DHHS 3377, clothing inventory to show this consultant.
Case Service Plan dated 11/17/20-2/13/21
There was no information documenting the Complainant could alter the school Foster
Child A was attending.
Social Work Contacts from 1/22/21-3/4/21:
There are no social work contacts (phone, email, in person) that document
conversations pertaining to transportation or change of school.
I was unable to review a DHS 3377 to verify thee amount of clothing Foster Child A had
when placed.
I reviewed DHHS Policy FOM 903-9:
6

If it is determined that it is in the child’s best interest to remain in the school
district of origin despite being placed in a foster home outside of the school
district, there may be an additional cost for transportation. MDHHS and the
school district can assist with this cost. Transportation should be set up in
collaboration with the school district foster care liaison and the caregiver to
identify the most cost-effective plan. Options for transportation include, but are
not limited to:
 Gas reimbursement to foster parent or volunteer driver.
The cost for transportation to the school of origin may be paid as follows:
 For a child who is in a Title IV-E funded placement, MDHHS
will pay the entire transportation expense.
 For a child who is in a non-Title IV-E funded placement,
MDHHS and the school district of origin split the cost 50/50.
 Local school districts and MDHHS staff may also collaborate to
agree on other payment options.
I reviewed the DHHS policy FOM 903-09:
A DHS-3377, Clothing Inventory Checklist, must be completed within the first 30
calendar days of every placement and again at every placement change. The
worker must make every effort to obtain available clothing from the child's own
home or previous placement. Clothing payments are only to be made to
providers who are also receiving maintenance payments.
Initial Clothing Payment
Initial clothing payments supplement a child's existing wardrobe and is not an
automatic allowance for every child entering care. The DHS-3377 must be
completed, uploaded to the documents hyperlink on the service authorization,
and filed in the child's case file to document need.
I reviewed the Foster Parent Orientation Manual signed by Complainant 1:
Clothing Policy:
An initial clothing allowance may be available when a child first enters care for foster
placement. A semi-annual clothing allowance occurs twice a year. The Clothing
Inventory Checklist (BRS 3377) should be used as a guideline in determining basic
(minimal) clothing needs.
The schedule of foster care rates designates a portion of the daily rate for the purchase
7

of clothing for foster children. Foster parents and the agency shall ensure that each
foster child has a sufficient amount of clothing that is size and season appropriate and
in good repair…
Transportation Policy:
Routine transportation which parents would normally provide for their child, (e.g.,
medical/dental appointments, school conferences, etc.) is covered in the age-
appropriate per diem reimbursement rate. No additional reimbursement is available.
Extraordinary transportation provided for the child, such as special long distance
medical appointments, is reimbursable upon discussion with the Huron County
Department of Health and Human Services worker for preauthorization.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12402 Program statement.
Program statement. An agency shall have and follow a
current written program statement that includes all of the
following information:
(c) Types of services provided to foster children and
their families.
8

ANALYSIS: Complainant 1 did not receive reimbursement for transportation
costs to and from school. Foster Child A attended a school
outside of Complainant 1’s school district. According to DHHS
policy, transportation reimbursement is to be provided in this
situation. According to the Foster Parent Orientation Manuel
signed by Complainant 1, this will fall under “extraordinary
transportation”.
Although TAT was contacted to provide transportation, this
transportation service was not realistic or in the best interest of
Foster Child A. This transportation would have resulted in Foster
Child A waking up early to catch a 6:00am bus when school did
not start until 8:00am. This would also result in Foster Child A
waiting 30 minutes after school to be transported.
Complainant 1 was not reimbursed for clothing that was bought
for Foster Child A. Neither the DHHS policy nor the Foster
Family Manual report a receipt is needed for reimbursement of
clothing. Complainant 1 did provide a receipt although it was not
needed. DHHS policy requires a DHHS 3377 to be completed
and provided for reimbursement, although one was not
completed and Complainant 1 was reimbursed for some clothing
money.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
A. It is recommended that the license remain unchanged.
